intro: Mentha todarii, commonly known as the Armenian mint, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and Central Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and produces small, pale blue or purple flowers. Its leaves are broadly ovate to lanceolate, with a serrated margin and a strongly menthol-like fragrance. Mentha todarii is often cultivated for its medicinal properties and as a ornamental plant in gardens.
